si0022.svg svg 2455 ALTIMG APCATA 120590 120590 S0926-860X(25)00492-2 10.1016/j.apcata.2025.120590 The Authors Fig. 1 XRD patterns of the as prepared catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Cu (top) and K (bottom) elemental mapping of (FeZn)1Cu4K (A-B), (FeZn)10Cu10K (C-D) and (FeZn10Cu)10K (E-F). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 H2 consumption during H2-TPR of (FeZn)1Cu4K, (FeZn)10Cu10K and (FeZn10Cu)10K in red, blue and black, respectively. Experimental conditions: 5 % H2/Ar, heating rate 10 °C/min, GHSV = 24 L(STP)/h/g. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 CO consumption during CO-TPR of (FeZn)1Cu4K, (FeZn)10Cu10K and (FeZn10Cu)10K in red, blue and black, respectively. Experimental conditions: 1.2 % CO/He, heating rate 10 °C/min, GHSV = 100 L(STP)/h/g. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Outlet flowrates and temperature with increasing Time of Activation (T.o.A). A) (FeZn)1Cu4K catalyst. B) (FeZn10)10Cu10K catalyst. C) (FeZn10Cu)10K catalyst. Experimental conditions: CO:H2= 1:2 vol:vol, P = 0 barg, GHSV = 6 L(STP)/h/gcat. Fig. 9 On the performances of highly promoted Fe-Zn-Cu-K catalysts for CO2 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Beda Rolandi Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation Visualization Conceptualization Mattia Piacentini Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation Visualization Conceptualization Riccardo Ometto Writing – review & editing Investigation Data curation Conceptualization Alessandro Porta Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Conceptualization ⁎ Carlo Giorgio Visconti Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Conceptualization Laboratory of Catalysis and Catalytic Processes, Department of Energy, Politecnico di Milano, via La Masa 34 2156, Milano, Italy Laboratory of Catalysis and Catalytic Processes Department of Energy Politecnico di Milano via La Masa 34 2156 Milano Italy Laboratory of Catalysis and Catalytic Processes (LCCP), Department of Energy, Politecnico di Milano, via La Masa 34 2156 Milano Italy ⁎ Corresponding author. A state-of-the-art Fischer-Tropsch 100Fe:10Zn:1Cu:4 K catalyst and catalysts promoted with higher Cu and K loadings were compared in terms of activity, selectivity and stability in the CO2 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Higher promoter loadings increased selectivity towards heavier hydrocarbons, with a minor impact on activity at high conversion conditions. In such conditions, both catalysts samples experienced activity loss possibly due to iron carbide oxidation at high water partial pressure, but while the state-of-the-art catalyst had also selectivity affected, the highly promoted catalyst preserved heavy products selectivity. Notably, the highly promoted catalyst could be successfully rejuvenated in-situ by decreasing pressure and increasing temperature under CO2/H2 flow. This procedure allowed to restore almost completely the initial activity while preserving an excellent C2 + hydrocarbon selectivity. On the contrary, the traditional Fischer-Tropsch catalyst, after the same rejuvenation treatment, showed a more pronounced selectivity shift towards lighter products. These findings can help in formulating stable catalysts that promote the one-pot synthesis of long chain hydrocarbons from CO2 at industrially relevant conditions. Graphical Abstract Keywords Iron-based catalyst Catalyst stability Deactivation Rejuvenation CCU CO2 Fischer-Tropsch Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The contemporary challenge of reducing net greenhouse gas emissions and decreasing dependence on fossil fuels requires a shift to sustainable energy [1]. Therefore, the possibility of converting mixtures of CO2 and green H2 into long-chain hydrocarbons has gained strong interest in recent years [2]. CO2 and H2 can be converted into long-chain hydrocarbons adopting a two-step process: firstly, CO2 is reduced to CO through the reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS, Eq. 1), then CO is converted into hydrocarbons via the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FT, Eq. 2) [3]. (1) CO 2 + H 2 → CO + H 2 O ΔH R 0 = + 41 kJ / mol (2) nCO + 2 nH 2 → − CH 2 − n + nH 2 O ΔH R 0 = − 170 kJ / mol CO Even though both the RWGS reaction and the FT synthesis reject oxygen in the form of water, if both reactions occur in the same reactor, process layout can be simplified and CO removal, thanks to FT synthesis, allows to reach CO2 conversion levels beyond what dictated by the sole RWGS equilibrium [4]. This process is typically referred to as Modified Fischer-Tropsch (MFT) or CO2 Fischer-Tropsch (CO2-FT). Iron-based catalysts are among the most promising CO2-FT catalysts, as iron can be present in the reaction environment in form of magnetite (Fe3O4), known to catalyze the RWGS, and in form of iron carbides (FexCy), able to catalyze the FT [5]. Accordingly, the coexistence of both phases at the actual process conditions is beneficial to improve CO2 hydrogenation [6]. An efficient strategy to improve the catalytic performance of CO2-FT on Fe-based catalysts is catalyst promotion. Compared to conventional FT, indeed, the lower CO2 adsorption strength with respect to CO results in a higher H/C ratio on the catalyst surface, which shifts CO2-FT product selectivity towards short-chain, saturated hydrocarbons [7]. In particular, promotion with alkali metals such as K or Na has been reported to be an efficient solution to increase selectivity towards long-chain hydrocarbons: the electronic effects induced by these metals increase COx dissociative adsorption [8,9] and decrease the H/C ratio on the catalyst surface, thereby improving selectivity towards long-chain hydrocarbons [9,10]. While alkali promotion is performed also on conventional FT catalyst in low quantities, it is common to find CO2-FT catalyst formulation with alkali loading higher than 10 %wt [5,11,12]. A drawback of the increase in alkalinity of the catalyst surface is that alkali metals may inhibit hydrogen activation [13], thereby decreasing both the intrinsic COx hydrogenation activity as well as the amount of active phase. This inhibition can lead to lower catalyst reducibility and, consequently, to a reduced formation of iron carbides. In fact, it has been demonstrated that the reduction of Fe₃O₄ to Fe⁰ is the rate-determining step in the formation of iron carbides [6]. Adding a reduction promoter such as Cu is a common strategy to compensate for the presence of alkali by enhancing Fe3O4 reduction and improving its carburization [14]. Indeed, it has been shown that Cu0 can enhance Fe reduction due to H2 spillover, facilitating its subsequent carburization during the activation phase [15]. Furthermore, in the specific case of syngas activated Fe-based catalysts, the presence of Cu can also increase the electron density of the catalyst surface, enhancing the carbon coverage and increasing the selectivity towards long-chain hydrocarbons [16,17]. Moreover, in the context of CO2-FT, Cu can be added to promote the RWGS [11,14,18], providing additional active sites for CO2 activation, thus increasing the overall conversion. Besides the high activity and the increased selectivity towards long-chain hydrocarbons, obtaining stable catalysts is another major challenge for CO2-FT. Indeed, Fe-based catalysts are known to suffer from deactivation, particularly at high CO2 conversions, since the high partial pressure of water may cause oxidation of iron carbides [19]. Furthermore, coking can cause pore blocking and the consequent decrease of accessible active sites for the FT reaction [20]. Notably, it has been observed that catalysts deactivated by active site oxidation can be regenerated in situ by feeding CO-containing streams [21]. However, to our knowledge no studies on the effect of promoter loading on the efficiency of catalyst regeneration are available in the literature. In this work, a conventional Fe-based FT catalyst has been prepared by Fe-Zn coprecipitation followed by Cu and K impregnation (Fe:Zn:Cu:K=100:10:1:4, atomic ratio). This catalyst formulation has been previously reported to exhibit good performance in CO2-FT [22]. Its performances have been compared with highly promoted catalysts: a first one prepared with the same method, but with higher Cu and K loadings (Fe:Zn:Cu:K=100:10:10:10, atomic ratio); a second one where Cu was coprecipitated together with Fe and Zn, and then impregnated with K (Fe:Zn:Cu:K=100:10:10:10, atomic ratio). The addition of Cu via co-precipitation was used aiming at a homogeneous Cu distribution, even at relatively high loadings. Evolution of performances during runs lasting more than 400 h allowed to track conversion and selectivity profiles, gaining insights on the role of Cu and K promotion on catalyst stability, activity and selectivity. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Two different synthesis methods were adopted to prepare in-house the catalyst samples studied in this work. The first synthesis procedure was performed according to the protocol reported by some of us in [22] and is briefly described below. A solution of Fe:Zn with atomic ratio of 100:10 was prepared by combining a solution of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (Sigma Aldrich) 3 M and a solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (Fluka) 1.4 M in deionized water. In parallel, a buffer solution of (NH4)2CO3 (Sigma Aldrich) 1.0 M was put in a jacketed stirred reactor and acidified to pH 7.0 by addition of HNO3. The buffer solution was then heated up to 80 °C, and the Fe/Zn solution was added dropwise. Throughout the entire dropping process, pH was kept constant at 7.0 ± 0.1 thanks to an electronic titrator (Metrohm, 719 S Titrino), which adjusted the pH by addition of (NH4)2CO3 (1.0 M) to the mother liquor. The solid product was then separated by filtration under pressure and washed repeatedly with 500 mL of water per washing step until neutral pH was reached. The obtained powder was dried for 12 h at 120 °C in static air, then temperature was increased to 350 °C in static air (1 h, heating rate: 1 °C/min). The obtained solid was then crushed to obtain a powder with a granulometry below 100 µm. About 10 g of calcined co-precipitated precursor were obtained using this procedure. Subsequently, Cu and K were added by incipient wetness impregnation with different loadings, starting from aqueous solutions of Cu(NO3)2 (Sigma Aldrich) and K2CO3 (Sigma Aldrich). In between Cu and K impregnation, the catalyst was dried in static air at 120 °C overnight. Eventually, the catalyst underwent a second thermal treatment at 400 °C in static air (4 h, heating rate: 1 °C/min). Two catalyst formulations were obtained with the following Fe:Zn:Cu:K atomic ratios: 100:10:1:4 and 100:10:10:10. The same batch of co-precipitated calcined precursor was used to obtain the final catalyst, yielding about 5 g for each catalyst formulation. In this work, the former catalyst is referred to as (FeZn)1Cu4K, while the latter is referred to as (FeZn)10Cu10K, where brackets enclose the co-precipitated species. A second preparation procedure was used to synthesize the third catalyst studied, using a procedure adapted from Hwang et al. [11]. The procedure was changed to allow for Cu to co-precipitate with Fe and Zn. The precursor was synthesized to get nominal composition of Fe:Zn:Cu= 100:10:10. To this aim, Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O (Sigma Aldrich) 0.5 M, Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O (Sigma Aldrich) 0.05 M, and Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O (Fluka) 0.05 M salts were dissolved in distilled water and combined in the desired ratio to obtain the precursor solution. The precipitating solution was prepared using K2CO3 (Sigma Aldrich), 0.6 M solution, added into a jacketed stirred reactor and heated to 80 °C. The precursor solution was added to the precipitating solution until the pH reached a value of 7.0. The solution was aged for 3 h at 80 °C under vigorous stirring. As per the previous procedure, the catalyst was then filtered, washed, dried and heated to 350 °C in static air (1 h, heating rate: 1 °C/min). About 10 g of calcined co-precipitated precursor were obtained using this procedure. K was then added through incipient wetness impregnation as per the previous procedure, so to obtain the final atomic composition of Fe:Zn:Cu:K equal to 100:10:10:10. The catalyst was then dried at 120 °C and then heated to 400 °C in static air (1 h, heating rate: 1 °C/min). In the following, this catalyst formulation will be referred to as (FeZn10Cu)10 K. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Catalysts specific surface area, average pore diameter and pore size distribution were computed by N2 physisorption at its normal boiling point, performed with a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 instrument. Specific surface area was computed using the BET method, while the average pore diameter was computed using the BJH method based on the adsorption branch of the N2 isotherm. A Panalytical Empyrean X-ray diffractometer (XRD) with a Cu-Kα radiation source was used to characterize the crystalline phases on the fresh catalysts. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on a Zeiss Sigma 500 microscope equipped with an Oxford Ultim Max 65 Aztec Energy Advanced energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) to analyze the catalyst morphology and its elemental composition. Hydrogen Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR) experiments, were carried out using a TPD/R/O 1100 Thermoquest instrument, featuring a micro-flow reactor with an internal diameter of 10 mm placed in an electric oven. Each test was carried out over 0.05 g of catalyst sample by feeding 5 % H2 in Ar (20 mL(STP)/min, corresponding to 24 L(STP)/h/g) and increasing temperature to 1050 °C (heating rate: 10 °C/min). CO Temperature Programmed Reduction (CO-TPR) experiments were carried out over 0.06 g of catalyst diluted with 0.06 g of α-Al2O3 in a quartz reactor placed in an electrically heated oven, flowing 1.2 % CO in He (100 mL(STP)/min, corresponding to 100 L(STP)/h/g) and increasing temperature to 800 °C (heating rate: 10 °C/min). The outlet gases were monitored with a MKS Multigas 2030 FT-IR spectrometer. 2.3 Catalyst testing For each run, 0.5 g of catalyst (particle diameter below 100 µm) were diluted with 5.5 g of α-Al2O3 (particle diameter: 74–105 µm) to achieve a 1:10 volumetric dilution. The catalytic bed was packed in a tubular reactor (stainless steel, AISI 316 L) with an inner diameter of 1.3 cm, which was in turn inserted in an electrically heated tubular oven. The temperature was monitored and controlled by a sliding K type thermocouple inside a 1/8” thermowell and placed in the center of the catalyst bed. The thermocouple was slid along the catalyst bed to measure the temperature profile, and the maximum temperature difference in the catalyst bed was always contained below 5 °C. Gases exiting from the reactor passed through a hot vessel (200 mL volume) kept at 130 °C to condense heavy hydrocarbons (i.e., waxes) and then through a dome-loaded back pressure regulator. The effluents, at atmospheric pressure, were sampled and analyzed every 45 min by an online gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 7820 A), equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). C1-C8 hydrocarbons were separated through an Al2O3-plot capillary column directly connected to the FID. H2, CO, CH4, N2 and Ar were separated with a molecular sieve column, while CO2 was separated in a Porapak Q column: both these columns were connected to the same TCD. After the GC, gases were sent to a cold trap kept at 2 °C and atmospheric pressure, from where the remaining condensable species were collected at the end of each experimental condition to compute integral carbon balances. Carbon balances, calculated as the sum of the overall carbon exiting the reactor divided by carbon entering, was always higher than 90 %. The carbon balance for each condition discussed in this paper is available in the supplementary material (Table S1 and S2). The catalyst was pretreated by feeding syngas (CO:H2 1:2 vol:vol with 2 % Ar used as internal standard) with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 6 L(STP)/h/gcat and by increasing temperature from room temperature to 270 °C (heating rate: 1 °C/min). After 1 h at 270 °C the temperature was lowered to 220 °C. During the pretreatment, total carbon deposition rate was computed as per Eq. (3), where ΔC indicates the flowrate of carbon deposited normalized by the catalyst mass loaded in the reactor, F i IN and F i OUT indicate the molar flowrate in mmol/h of the i-th species at the reactor inlet and outlet, respectively. (3) ΔC = F CO in − F CO out − F CO 2 out − F CH 4 out m cat By integrating ΔC over time the moles of carbon deposited during pretreatment normalized by the catalyst mass are obtained. After the activation procedure, the reaction mixture (CO2:H2 1:3 vol:vol with 2 % Ar used as internal standard) was fed with a GHSV of 6 L(STP)/h/gcat and pressure was increased to 30 barg (3 bar/h). When pressure reached 30 bar, time on stream (T.o.S.) was set to 0 h. CO2 conversion and product selectivities were computed as per Eqs. 4–7: (4) CO 2 conversion = F CO 2 in − F CO 2 out F CO 2 in (5) Sel CO = F CO out F CO 2 in − F CO 2 out (6) Sel CH 4 = F CH 4 out F CO 2 in − F CO 2 out (7) Sel C 2 + = 1 − Sel CO − Sel CH 4 Water flowrate at the reactor outlet was computed as per Eq. (8) via oxygen balance, neglecting the minor molar contribution of oxygenate compounds found in the reaction products. (8) F H 2 O out = 2 F CO 2 in − F CO 2 out − F CO out The difference between outlet water flowrate computed as per Eq. (8) through the periodical liquid product collection from the hot and cold trap was always below 5 %. The distribution of C1-C8 hydrocarbons measured by the on-line gas chromatograph will be shown in terms of Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) distribution. To create the ASF plot, molar fractions in the hydrocarbon pool were computed as per Eq. (9), where HCi indicates the i-th hydrocarbon: (9) y HC i = F HC i out ∑ i = 1 8 F HC i out The equilibrium approach was used for the RWGS reaction. The reaction quotient was computed as per Eq. (10), where P i indicates the partial pressure of the i-th species considered. (10) k p = P CO P H 2 O P CO 2 P H 2 k p was then divided by the equilibrium constant, k eq , yielding the parameter k p / k eq used to indicate the proximity to the equilibrium (at the chemical equilibrium, k p / k eq =1). k eq was calculated through Aspen Plus V10 using the Gibbs Reactor tool (RGibbs). 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst characterization XRD diffractograms of the three catalysts prepared and tested in this paper are shown in Fig. 1. The (FeZn)1Cu4K sample, shown in red, shows presence of crystalline α-Fe2O3 and γ-Fe2O3. Peaks related to Fe3O4 or ZnFe2O4 are also observed, but a clear distinction between the two phases is not possible due to their superimposable diffraction patterns. By using Scherrer’s equation on the diffraction peak at 2θ= 49.3° it is possible to calculate an average Fe2O3 crystal size of 18 nm. (FeZn)10Cu10K catalyst, in blue in Fig. 1, shows two broad peaks around 2θ= 30°-40° and 2θ = 60°-65°, highlighting a low crystallinity of the catalyst sample, which makes unreliable the identification of Fe phases. Considering that the same preparation method was adopted for the bulk phase of (FeZn)1Cu4K and (FeZn)10Cu10K, the observed differences suggest that high promoters loading can prevent the formation of large Fe crystallites. (FeZn10Cu)10K, in black in Fig. 1, is characterized by peaks related only to Fe3O4 or ZnFe2O4. The average size of the crystals can be calculated by Scherrer’s equation (8 nm considering the peak at 2θ=49.3°). Surface area, pore volume and average pore diameters are given in Table S.3 of the Supplementary Material. Notably, different synthesis methods and recipes resulted in materials with similar morphological properties, exhibiting surface area close to 100 m2/g and average pore diameter around 10 nm. Cu and K EDS maps are shown in Fig. 2 for the three samples. Corresponding SEM images and EDS maps of Fe and Zn are shown in Figure S1, S2 and S3 of the Supplementary material, together with the evaluated atomic ratios in the three samples (Table S.4) Cu and K appear homogeneously distributed on (FeZn)1Cu4K (Fig. 2 A, B) and (FeZn10Cu)10 K (Fig. 2 E, F) surfaces. In the case of (FeZn)10Cu10K (Fig. 2 C, D), instead, clusters of Cu and K are evident on the catalyst surface. Therefore, our results highlight that high Cu loading causes clustering on a micrometric scale when Cu is added via impregnation, probably influencing the consecutive K dispersion which also shows large agglomerates. On the other hand, co-precipitation allows to obtain a homogeneous sample. Fig. 3 shows the H2 consumption measured during H2-TPR experiments. (FeZn)1Cu4K shows an initial hydrogen consumption starting around 250 °C, with peak consumption at 300 °C. This reduction peak is associated to the reduction of Fe2O3 into Fe3O4 [23]. Interestingly, the onset of H2 consumption is anticipated at lower temperatures on the two samples with higher promoter loading, indicating a promotion in the reducibility from Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. Notably, (FeZn)10Cu10K shows a split reduction peak below 450 °C, indicating a possible sequential reduction of Cu followed by Fe. In contrast, (FeZn10Cu)10 K exhibits a more uniform peak, suggesting that Cu and Fe reduction occur in a more similar temperature range. This difference can be ascribed to the presence of exposed Cu clusters, as evidenced by SEM-EDS, which makes the Cu reduction clearly visible in the TPR profile in the case of (FeZn)10Cu10K. Nevertheless, beyond 450 °C, all catalysts exhibit a similar H2 consumption, indicating a similar reduction kinetics from Fe3O4 to Fe0. This trend appears evident in Figure S4 of the supplementary material, which reports the cumulative H₂ consumption for each sample, showing nearly parallel profiles in the 500–800 °C temperature range. The reducibility of the catalysts has been further evaluated via CO-TPR, shown in Fig. 4 as CO consumption profiles. In all cases, CO2 was observed in the effluents (not shown in Fig. 4), with an evolution profile closely resembling the CO consumption one. (FeZn)1Cu4K shows three typical reduction peaks, where the first is associated with the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, while subsequent peaks are associated with the concurrent reduction and carburization of Fe3O4 [24]. With respect to the corresponding H2 consumption profiles (Fig. 3), all CO consumption peaks are shifted to lower temperatures, indicating the easier reduction of hematite and magnetite in the presence of CO. The highly promoted samples show a similar profile, but the onset of CO consumption is shifted towards lower temperatures with respect to (FeZn)1Cu4K, suggesting a favored reduction from Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. Interestingly, the further reduction of Fe3O4 exhibits a comparable onset for all catalysts formulations, occurring at around 320 °C. In close analogy with H2-TPR results, these results highlight that highly promoted samples show an improved reduction Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, while the reduction from Fe3O4 to Fe0 is comparable between all the samples in the conditions of interest for in-situ catalyst activation. 3.2 Catalyst activation Given the critical role of activation in Fe-based catalysts, monitoring the evolution of the composition of outlet gases during in-situ pretreatment with 6 L(STP)/h/gcat of syngas (CO:H2=1:2 vol:vol), it is useful to gain insights on the catalyst transformation during this phase. Fig. 5 shows the evolution of the outlet flowrates as a function of the Time of Activation (T.o.A) for (FeZn)1Cu4K (A), (FeZn)10Cu10K (B) and (FeZn10Cu)10K (C) catalysts. For the sample containing less promoters, CO and H2 consumption occurs simultaneously at approximately 230 °C. As CO consumption occurs, CO2, CH4 and C2-C3 olefins are detected at the reactor outlet. While CO2 production can be attributed to different reactions such as Fe oxides reduction with CO [16], carbon deposition and carbides formation [25], the presence of hydrocarbons can be attributed to the formation of iron carbides, the active phase required for hydrocarbons formation. The detection of hydrocarbons already at 230 °C indicates that the reduction and carburization of Fe3O4 is significantly shifted towards lower temperatures compared to the results obtained during CO-TPR. We speculate that this effect can be attributed to the presence of superficial H2 which, removing oxygen from the lattice of iron oxides, allows to free active sites for carburization, that can occur at lower temperatures compared to the case of CO-TPR [26], and/or to the much higher CO and H2 partial pressure. Although our setup does not allow to distinguish between different forms of deposited carbon (amorphous carbon, graphitic carbon and iron carbides [27]), evidence of carbon deposition (17 mmolC/gcat) and the detection of hydrocarbons are in line with the formation of iron carbides. Highly promoted catalysts exhibit similar onset temperature for CO and H2 consumption (230 °C), but the formation of hydrocarbons is delayed. This delay can be ascribed to a lower hydrogen coverage on the catalyst surface, caused by competitive CO and H2 adsorption [9], which is increasingly unfavorable for H2 with higher K loadings [28]. Notably, the increased amount of Cu of the highly promoted samples does not seem sufficient to counter this effect [28]. Despite the Cu and K clustering in (FeZn)10Cu10K highlighted by SEM-EDS, both highly promoted catalysts show comparable behavior during activation. This finding is consistent with H2- and CO-TPR results, which indicate that differences in preparation mainly affect the reduction from Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, while the subsequent Fe3O4 reduction - i.e., the rate-determining step for the formation of Fe carbides [6] - proceeds similarly for all preparations. Consequently, promoter homogeneity appears to play a limited role in carburization at the investigated loadings under the present activation conditions. However, it cannot be excluded that additional phenomena during activation such as migration of Cu and K, may affect the catalyst structure and possibly limit the potential benefits of promoter loading and distribution. The carbon balance evaluated for the same activation tests shown in Fig. 5 is shown in Figure S5 of the Supplementary Material. Interestingly, for the highly promoted samples carbon deposition is observed even before hydrocarbon production begins, possibly indicating that some of the carbon deposited on the catalysts does not contribute to form catalytically active species. Despite this, carbon deposition profiles for the three catalysts indicate that the onset and extent of overall carbon deposition are comparable for all catalysts. 3.3 Catalyst activity and selectivity Fig. 6 shows the on-line results of the first 225 h of the runs, where the temperature effect was investigated (from 220 to 300 °C). Already at 220 °C, all the catalysts are active to convert CO2 into long-chain hydrocarbons. However, CO2 conversion almost doubles on highly promoted catalysts with respect to (FeZn)1Cu4K. To gain insights into CO2 reactivity and to separate the effects of increased CO2 conversion rate between the RWGS and FT, it is useful to evaluate the equilibrium approach of the RWGS at the outlet of the bed (Shown in Figure S.6). Interestingly, k p RWGS / k eq RWGS is close to 0.5 for highly promoted catalysts, and below 0.2 for (FeZn)1Cu4K, suggesting that, at this temperature, the RWGS reaction is under kinetic control for all the catalysts. Our results align with the work by Meng et al. [29], where it was observed that at low temperature (i.e., at low conversion) the RWGS kinetically limits overall CO2 conversion. The enhanced activity and selectivity towards long chain hydrocarbons (C2+) of the highly promoted catalysts can be explained considering that, although a similar carbon deposition has been measured during activation, under actual reaction conditions they can retain a higher fraction of active carbide species. This would imply that (FeZn)1Cu4K may undergo a higher degree of carbon deposition as inactive carbon during activation. Nevertheless, since the RWGS reaction is under kinetic control, the higher overall activity could also arise from an increased RWGS rate due to the higher Cu content [14] and increased CO2 adsorption associated with the higher alkali load [13]. Upon temperature increase to 270 °C, all catalysts show a similar increase in CO2 conversion of about 20 %, since increasing temperature favors both RWGS and FT kinetics. All catalysts show an initial peak in CO2 conversion which is significantly higher than the equilibrium conversion of the sole RWGS reaction at 270 °C. This increase in CO2 conversion can be explained by a synergy between RWGS and FT: FT reaction, by consuming CO, can increase the rate of overall CO2 conversion thanks to a thermodynamic equilibrium shift. Notably, highly promoted catalysts show higher initial conversion (34 % for both (FeZn)10Cu10K and (FeZn10Cu)10K, compared to 26 % for (FeZn)1Cu4K), which can be again attributed to a promoted RWGS activity and to a higher content of active Fe-carbide at the actual reaction conditions. After the initial activity peaks, all catalyst formulations lose activity with time on stream. This behavior can be attributed to the oxidation of iron carbides due to increased partial pressure of water with consequent loss of FT active phase [19], that progressively hinders the synergistic effect between RWGS and FT. Also the loss of RWGS kinetic boost due to Cu and K migration cannot be excluded [30]. However, the hydrocarbon distribution remains substantially unchanged with time-on-stream (ASF variations with time on stream shown in Supplementary Material, Figure S.7). This observation suggests that the loss of activity should be attributed primarily to a progressive oxidation of iron carbides, but the residual active centers retain their intrinsic selectivity, as the beneficial effect of Cu and K on the selectivity is preserved [19,30]. The activity loss is more pronounced in highly promoted catalysts since the initial conversion peak results in water partial pressure around 5.5 bar at the reactor outlet, which is 1.5 bar higher with respect to that obtained in the case of the (FeZn)1Cu4K. The values of water partial pressure at the reactor outlet as a function of time on stream for the conditions reported in Fig. 6 are shown in Figure S.8 of the Supplementary Material. Performances evolve at 270 °C until the activity decrease slows down and water partial pressure reaches 4 bar for highly promoted catalysts and 3.5 bar for (FeZn)1Cu4K. Notably, this stabilization occurs at a similar value of water partial pressure and results in steady state performances which are similar for all catalysts, suggesting that water and hydrogen surface coverages produce equal Fe oxidation and reduction rates [31]. Increasing temperature to 300 °C leads to a further increase in CO2 conversion. The k p RWGS / k eq RWGS ratio gets close to 0.8 (Supplementary Material, Figure S.6), indicating that the RWGS reaction is approaching its equilibrium at the outlet of the bed. Nevertheless, CO2 conversion is significantly higher than that predictable at the equilibrium of the sole RWGS, due to the equilibrium shift given by CO consumption via FT reaction. Similarly to what observed at 270 °C, CO2 conversion peaks just after temperature is raised to 300 °C, but then is mitigated during time on stream, with performances stabilizing when the water partial pressure at the reactor outlet reaches a value such that further catalyst oxidation is not occurring. This value is found to be similar for all catalysts, around 5 bar at 300 °C. Results shown in Fig. 6 highlight that steady state activity differences between catalyst formulations are less pronounced as temperature increases. We attribute this phenomenon to RWGS reaction progressively approaching thermodynamic equilibrium, which overcompensates for any kinetic boosts on the RWGS due to improved formulations, combined with iron carbide oxidation above certain water partial pressure level, that penalizes the FT activity, thus limiting CO removal from the reaction environment and hence the overall CO2 conversion. To highlight differences in the product distribution on the three samples, Fig. 7 shows the ASF hydrocarbon distribution at steady state at 270 °C and 300 °C for the same test shown in Fig. 6. The samples containing more Cu and K are characterized by a lower selectivity towards C1-C3 species and a higher chain growth probability, indicating that high promoters loading can significantly influence product distribution. As already observed in Section 3.2 while discussing catalysts activation, highly loaded catalysts exhibit inhibited H2 activation due to the competitive COx adsorption which is enhanced by alkali-rich surfaces [9,28], leading to lower H/C ratio on the catalyst surface, thus promoting chain growth probability. Furthermore, the H/C ratio on the catalyst surface may also be influenced by the presence of Cu. Indeed, for syngas activated Fe-based catalysts, copper can be present as Cu+, where it can act as an electron donor and decrease the H/C ratio [16]. A similar effect cannot be excluded for our samples, thereby contributing to improved selectivity observed for the highly promoted catalysts. Notably, in close analogy with the observations discussed in Section 3.2, the method of Cu incorporation into the catalyst appears to have only a minor influence on hydrocarbon selectivity under the investigated operating conditions. Indeed, since (FeZn)10Cu10K and (FeZn10Cu)10 K already showed close activation profiles, we speculate that the two materials reach a comparable state after activation, which results in similar behavior under CO2-FT conditions. 3.4 Catalyst deactivation and rejuvenation In Section 3.3 we highlighted that all catalysts show evolving CO2 conversion over time-on-stream, possibly caused by iron carbide oxidation. This evolution is more pronounced at high CO2 conversion levels, i.e., at the conditions of interest for the industrial deployment of the process. Therefore, we verified whether promoters could affect catalyst stability at high conversion conditions, which is a major challenge in iron-based CO2 hydrogenation to long-chain hydrocarbons. The results of the experiments performed to assess the stability of (FeZn)1Cu4K and (FeZn10Cu)10K catalysts are shown in Figs. 8 and 9, respectively. The figures show the operative conditions adopted with evolving time on stream in the top panels, the catalyst performances, in terms of CO2 conversion and products selectivity with evolving time on stream, in the middle ones, and the ASF product distributions in selected conditions, in the bottom ones. Conditions (I) and (II) in Figs. 8 and 9 show stable performances. Indeed, both catalysts show comparable trends, in line with those previously discussed in Section 3.3: CO2 conversion is close to 35 % at 300 °C and 15 bar (Condition (I)), and it increases to around 45 % when temperature is increased to 350 °C (Condition (II)). While CO selectivity is equal for both the catalysts, CH4 selectivity is higher for (FeZn)1Cu4K in both conditions and C2+ is lower, indicating that (FeZn10Cu)10 K consistently outperforms (FeZn)1Cu4K in producing long-chain hydrocarbons. Nevertheless, both catalysts exhibit CO2 conversion and CO selectivity that tend to level off after initial evolution. Considering the ASF distribution in condition (I), moreover, it is observed that hydrocarbon distribution does not change throughout the condition tested. When conditions are changed to (III), both catalysts initially reach a CO2 conversion peak around 50 %, then progressively lose activity, to stabilize after approximately 100 h at CO2 conversion around 45 %. However, significant differences arise in product distribution. (FeZn)1Cu4K, shown in Fig. 8, shows a progressive evolution of hydrocarbon selectivity, with the ASF curve shifting towards lighter products. In contrast, (FeZn10Cu)10 K, shown in Fig. 9, exhibits a more stable hydrocarbon distribution, with the ASF distribution showing modest differences with increasing T.o.S. Water partial pressure at the reactor outlet for (FeZn)1Cu4K and (FeZn10Cu)10 K in the same tests is shown in the Supplementary Material, Figure S.9 and S.10 , respectively. In condition (III), water partial pressure at the reactor outlet reaches values as high as 9 bar for both catalysts. Accordingly, the marked shift in product selectivity observed with (FeZn)1Cu4K during condition (III) can be attributed to exposure to high partial pressure of water, which causes a strong modification of the alkali promotion on the catalyst surface. Indeed, alkali migration from the FT active centers is a known phenomenon occurring on Fe-based FT catalysts [30,32], that is enhanced at higher values of water partial pressure [33]. This potentially reduces the adsorption strength of CO/CO2 on FT sites, thereby increasing the H/C ratio on the catalyst surface, progressively shifting the product distribution towards lighter products. Moreover, the high partial pressure of water can also have caused a migration of Cu, which is known to sinter when exposed at high partial pressure of water and high temperature [34], reducing its effectiveness in promoting carburization [16] and selectivity to long-chain hydrocarbons [17]. We speculate that hydrocarbon distribution variations are significantly less pronounced for (FeZn10Cu)10 K, as its higher promoters loading helps to mitigate the effect of their eventual loss of efficacy, ultimately stabilizing the performance under condition of high partial pressure of water, thus preserving the C-C coupling capability. Conditions (IV) and (V) shown in Figs. 8 and 9 are used as activity check points. By comparing results under the same operating conditions, i.e. (I) vs. (V) and (II) vs. (IV), it is evident that both catalysts are deactivated, showing a comparable loss of CO2 conversion and increase in CO selectivity. For what concerns the selectivity, (FeZn10Cu)10 K shows a consistent hydrocarbon distribution, while (FeZn)1Cu4K confirms its tendency to produce lighter hydrocarbons. The loss of CO2 conversion experienced by both catalysts can be attributed to the oxidation of iron carbides caused by exposure to high partial pressure of water during condition (III) [19]. This deactivation, however, may in principle be reversible. In CO2 hydrogenation, Fe is known to undergo a dynamic evolution between oxidation and carburization, with some operating conditions providing thermodynamic and kinetic driving force for iron carbide oxidation [31]. Therefore, it results relevant to investigate if, by appropriately tuning the operating conditions, it is possible to promote carbide formation rather than oxidation. Here, these conditions are reproduced as condition (VI) in Figs. 8 and 9, where temperature is set to 350 °C and pressure decreased to 5 barg. The evolution trend is similar for both catalysts: an initial peak in CO selectivity is observed (70 % for (FeZn)1Cu4K and 85 % for (FeZn10Cu)10 K), which then progressively decreases as CO2 conversion and hydrocarbon selectivity increases. This behavior provides strong evidence for the regeneration of FT active phase, that promotes hydrocarbon production and shifts overall CO2 conversion beyond the RWGS equilibrium by removing CO from the reaction environment. However, at the end of condition (VI), a significant difference between the catalysts can be observed: (FeZn)1Cu4K catalyst stabilizes around 25 % CO selectivity and 35 % CO2 conversion, whereas (FeZn10Cu)10 K reaches 40 % CO selectivity and 28 % CO2 conversion. These results suggest that (FeZn10Cu)10 K is slower to regenerate the FT active centers. We speculate that the difference in the carburation rate during condition (VI) can be attributed to the different H2 activation capability shown by the catalyst formulations, already observed in Section 3.2: here, this difference might be further enhanced, since the main catalyst reduction is done by H2. High K loadings have been shown to result in decreased H coverages: as a consequence, the catalyst reduction step needed before Fe-carburization is slowed down [35]. Nevertheless, our findings show that regeneration is possible to some extent with the same H2/CO2 feed mixture for both catalysts. Indeed, as shown in Figure S.9 and S.10, results obtained at 350 °C suggest that FT phase regeneration is enhanced when water partial pressure is sufficiently low (i.e., when the system pressure was set to 5 bar) to minimize catalyst re-oxidation. A final activity check point is shown in condition (VII). For (FeZn)1Cu4K, activity is fully recovered, with CO2 conversion in condition (VII) reaching substantially the same level measured in condition (I). In contrast, (FeZn10Cu)10 K shows only a partial activity recovery, with CO2 conversion in condition (VII) lower than that achieved in condition (I). An opposite trend is observed in terms of hydrocarbon distribution: (FeZn)1Cu4K maintains its tendency to produce light hydrocarbons (CH4 increases from 11 % in condition (I) to 17 % in condition (VII)), while (FeZn10Cu)10 K better preserves selectivity towards long-chain hydrocarbons, with ASF distributions in condition (I) and (VII) which are nearly identical. While a strong activity recovery is observed for both catalysts, the results point out that an easier carburation does not necessarily imply the better recovery of selectivity towards heavy hydrocarbons: this is likely due to the possible promoter migration experienced by (FeZn)1Cu4K at the high water partial pressure, which is not reversible. 4 Conclusions In this work, the performances of a state-of-the-art FT Fe-based catalyst, referred to as (FeZn)1Cu4K, with a composition Fe:Zn:Cu:K= 100:10:1:4 (atomic ratio), has been compared with two highly promoted catalyst, with composition Fe:Zn:Cu:K= 100:10:10:10 (atomic ratio). The two highly promoted catalysts differ in the method of Cu incorporation: in the so-called “(FeZn)10Cu10K” Cu is added via incipient wetness impregnation on a co-precipitated FeZn support, while for “(FeZn10Cu)10 K” Cu was co-precipitated with iron and zinc. Our results highlight that increasing Cu and K loadings promotes catalyst activity at temperatures below 270 °C, where RWGS kinetically limits the rate of CO2 conversion. However, at temperature sufficiently high to approach RWGS equilibrium, promoters effect on the RWGS kinetic becomes less pronounced, and the steady-state performances are levelized for all the catalysts, with steady-state conversion limited by the maximum water partial pressure that the catalyst can tolerate without showing deactivation. Highly promoted catalysts, however, show always higher selectivity towards long-chain hydrocarbons compared to the less promoted catalyst. Under high CO2 conversion conditions, both (FeZn)1Cu4K and (FeZn10Cu)10 K catalysts exhibit activity loss with time on stream, confirming that high water partial pressure causes a progressive oxidation of iron carbides resulting in lower steady-state CO2 conversion. However, while (FeZn)1Cu4K catalyst also shows a progressive product shift toward short-chain hydrocarbons as CO2 conversion decreases, (FeZn10Cu)10K maintains a stable hydrocarbon distribution throughout 1000 h of testing. This has been ascribed to a mitigated impact of promoters’ migration when the catalyst is operated at high partial pressure of water in the case of (FeZn10Cu)10 K, that allows to better preserve the selectivity to long-chain hydrocarbons. This work proposes a strategy for the in-situ rejuvenation of a deactivated catalyst, able to successfully restore most of the activity and the selectivity to condensable products without changing the H2/CO2 feed. By simply increasing temperature and decreasing pressure, it is possible to drive the formation of novel FT active phase by keeping the oxidating potential of the reaction environment low, preventing further oxidation. After the rejuvenation treatment (FeZn)1Cu4K catalyst shows increased selectivity towards lighter hydrocarbons, indicating that the shift in product distribution experienced during exposure at high partial pressure of water, likely caused by promoters’ migration and sintering, is irreversible. In contrast, (FeZn10Cu)10 K catalyst preserves its original product distribution, demonstrating that the rejuvenation treatment does not have any undesired effect on the catalyst reactivity. As the mechanisms that dictate the catalyst deactivation and rejuvenation are multiple and complex to say the least (e.g., active phase oxidation, coking, promoters’ migration…), further physical-chemistry studies will be carried out to gain more insights into these aspects. To conclude, our results highlight that a higher promoter content, besides improving selectivity, significantly enhances stability under high CO2 conversion conditions, which are of interest for the industrial deployment of the technology. A highly promoted catalyst not only recovers its activity by facilitating the formation of novel active carbides from deactivated iron oxide centers but also reduces the effect of possible loss of promoters on the selectivity, ensuring more stable performances under demanding operating conditions. Lee, “Fischer–Tropsch on Iron with H 2 /CO and H 2 /CO 2 as Synthesis Gases: The Episodes of Formation of the Fischer–Tropsch Regime and Construction of the Catalyst,” Top Catal, vol. 26, no. 1–4, pp. 41–54, Dec. 2003, doi: 10.1023/B:TOCA.0000012986.46680.28.

coredata.dc:description: A state-of-the-art Fischer-Tropsch 100Fe:10Zn:1Cu:4 K catalyst and catalysts promoted with higher Cu and K loadings were compared in terms of activity, selectivity and stability in the CO2 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Higher promoter loadings increased selectivity towards heavier hydrocarbons, with a minor impact on activity at high conversion conditions. In such conditions, both catalysts samples experienced activity loss possibly due to iron carbide oxidation at high water partial pressure, but while the state-of-the-art catalyst had also selectivity affected, the highly promoted catalyst preserved heavy products selectivity. Notably, the highly promoted catalyst could be successfully rejuvenated in-situ by decreasing pressure and increasing temperature under CO2/H2 flow. This procedure allowed to restore almost completely the initial activity while preserving an excellent C2 + hydrocarbon selectivity. On the contrary, the traditional Fischer-Tropsch catalyst, after the same rejuvenation treatment, showed a more pronounced selectivity shift towards lighter products. These findings can help in formulating stable catalysts that promote the one-pot synthesis of long chain hydrocarbons from CO2 at industrially relevant conditions.
